Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Analytical Rheology and the Dynamics of Polymer Melts
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This CAREER award supports theoretical and computational research and education that seeks to develop novel algorithms to infer the architecture of polymer melts from rheological data. Addition of trace amounts of long-chain branching improves the processability of polymer melts. Despite its industrial importance, and advances in synthesis, which enable us to control the amount of branching, standard analytical methods such as chromatography and spectroscopy cannot reliably diagnose these trace levels. Rheology, on the other hand, is extremely sensitive to molecular architecture. This motivates the PI to investigate inverting contemporary models, based on the tube theory and hierarchical relaxation.

The proposed algorithms are based on the idea of Bayesian inference, which is used to transform the inverse problem of inferring structure, into a sampling problem, that is attacked using Markov chain Monte Carlo methods. This approach has four unique advantages: (i) It can be applied to systems with an unknown number of species; (ii) It has a built-in Occam's razor, which prefera less complex solutions, (iii) It can characterize multiple solutions, and (iv) It can incorporate complementary analytical information in a systematic and robust manner.

Contemporary rheological models, however, are less-than-perfect, and effort is directed in this project, at addressing these shortcomings by microscopic studies. In particular, we seek to study blends of cyclic and linear polymers to understand the process of constraint release, and to map physically different microscopic simulation models to understand the role of assumptions in coarse-graining.

This project will promote teaching, training and learning by continuing undergraduate and graduate participation in the research effort. The PI's association with an HBCU will provide a conduit for the participation of minority students in the research. This together with various strategies will help broaden participation. The PI will use computation to emphasize the connection between the microscopic structure and motion and macroscopic properties and phenomena of materials. Educational tools developed will be distributed through the PI's website.


NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This CAREER award supports theoretical and computational research and education that seeks to develop novel algorithms to infer the structure of large molecules that have long branched chain-like structures through rheology. Rheology involves measuring how these materials respond to deformation. Addition of trace amounts of long-chain branching improves the processability of these molecules known broadly as polymers. Despite its industrial importance standard analytical experimental methods cannot reliably diagnose these trace levels. Rheology, on the other hand, is extremely sensitive to molecular architecture, and motivates the PI to consider using contemporary models based on sophisticated microscopic theories in a direction reversed from the usual way they are used. This process is called analytical rheology, and is an ill-posed problem, which seriously impairs current methods. The research will develop a method that addresses the most serious shortcomings, which includes the inability to discriminate the number of components and to address the multiplicity of possible structures. This project also involves improving the contemporary models of polymers that would be used in reverse.

This project will promote teaching, training and learning by continuing undergraduate and graduate participation in the research effort. The PI's association with an HBCU will provide a conduit for the participation of minority students in the research. This together with various strategies will help broaden participation. The PI will use computation to emphasize the connection between the microscopic structure and motion and macroscopic properties and phenomena of materials. Educational tools developed will be distributed through the PI's website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We know that chain branching structure affects important properties of commerical plastics, but we do not yet have experimental protocols that are senstive enough to diagnose it reliably. A promising approach called "analytical rheology"  seeks to interpret data from special mechanical tests (small-angle oscillatory shear measurements), using theoretical models to infer branching structure. Different structures often have similar mechanical behavior, and it important to recognize the multiplicity of possible scenarios in inverse problems like analytical rheology. In this project, we developed and refined a statistical technique based on Bayesian inference, which allows us to leverage theoretical models of polymer dynamics to enumerate all the possible structures consistent with a given oscillatory shear test. We tested this algorithm on commerical metallocene catalyzed polyethylenes, which is a soup of polymers of different architectures, and were able to correctly identify the average level of branching. We used clustering methods to project multiple solutions sampled by the algorithm in a high-dimensional space in a graphically digestible manner. When additional experimental data (from chromatography, for example) is available, we figured out how to eliminate some of the possible candidate structures. We developed techniques to help identify the additional experiments, usually by blending the unknown sample with a well-characterized linear polymer, that ought to be performed to best resolve the multiplicity of solutions, and uniquely pin down the branching structure.


The theoretical models, based on a phenomenological theory called the "tube model", used as the engine in analytical rheology are imperfect. Blends of rings and linear polymers offer an interesting platform to improve our understanding of polymer dynamics, in part because the tube model relies on the diffusion of chain ends, and rings are "endless". We performed molecular simulations of ring and linear polymers, and discovered several interesting features that are not observed in linear or branched polymers. Perhaps, the most interesting observation is what happens to a single ring polymer immersed in a sea of linear polymers, as the molecular weight of the linear matrix is changed. If we track the diffusivity of the ring, we find that it is non-monotonic: it initially rises as the length of the linear chains increases, and beyond a certain point reverses course, and starts to decrease. This is quite counterintuitive, as the mobility of the underlying matrix is monotonic; it decreases with the molecular weight of the linear polymers. Indeed, if we replace the single ring "tracer" with a linear polymer, the non-monotonicity in diffusivity disappears. It turns out that there is subtle interplay between the topology and entanglement structure, which manifests itself in an unusual dynamic signature.


During the course of this project, six minority students (four graduate and two undergraduate) were mentored on computational and theoretical aspects of materials modeling. In addition the grant provided research funding to fully support for 1 PhD student (Arsia Takeh), and partially support 4 other graduate students. Two new courses ``Computational Materials Science" and ``Markov-chain Monte Carlo" were developed, and administered. The uniting theme of the latter course was Bayesian inference, which underpinned one of the research goals of this project.


The project also led to work that was initially unanticipated, but ultimately fruitful. While working on analytical rheology, we needed to extract relaxation spectra from linear viscoelastic measurements. Once, we realized that existing softare was either expensive, or difficult to work with, we wrote an open-source freely available program called ReSpect, which has been downloaded over 1500 times. Similarly, when we performed diffusivity measurements on tracer ring-linear blends, we were initially so unconvinced by the surprising non-monotonicty, that we spent two years to develop an algorithm called BOOTDIFF, which uses bootstrap sampling, to arrive at better estimates of uncertainty in the simulated diffusion constants. The usefulness of both ReSpect and BOOTDIFF is much wider than the confines of this particular project.
